share_language: #SCOTUS top cases: What you need to know
head: Supreme Court Decision Tracker
chatter: USA TODAY’s Richard Wolf breaks down what you need to know about the major cases coming before the Supreme Court in a term suddenly thrust into turmoil by the death of Justice Antonin Scalia.

cases.quote_2: “To say that a punishment might be inappropriate and disproportionate for certain juvenile offenders is not to say that it is unconstitutionally void.”
cases.quote_1: “Prisoners like Montgomery must be given the opportunity to show their crime did not reflect irreparable corruption; and, if it did not, their hope for some years of life outside prison walls must be restored."
cases.argument_against: The state said Supreme Court precedent bars retroactive application of most new criminal rules, and that applying the new standard to previously sentenced prisoners would lead to “burdensome relitigation of facts buried in the past or irretrievably lost.”
cases.title: Juvenile justice
cases.question: Does Miller v. Alabama, a 2012 Supreme Court case that banned mandatory life-without-parole sentences for juveniles convicted of murder, apply retroactively to those already serving life terms?
cases.analysis: The court ruled 6-3 that prisoners whose crimes were committed before they turned 18 deserve a resentencing hearing or an opportunity at parole, because the 2012 ruling was a substantive change that should apply retroactively.
cases.argument_for: Because the court has determined that children are constitutionally different from adults and cannot receive death sentences or mandatory life sentences, lawyers for Montgomery said the same should be true for those sentenced long ago as juveniles.

cases.quote_2: “Three out of the four African Americans who were struck were women. ... How does that affect the analysis?”
cases.quote_1: “It doesn’t really matter that there might have been a bunch of valid reasons out there, if it was clear that the prosecutor was thinking about race.”
cases.argument_against: Prosecutors maintain the black jurors were struck for race-neutral reasons, based on their families, occupations and addresses, that could make them favor Foster’s planned defense on grounds of temporary insanity, drug and alcohol abuse, and a deprived background.
cases.title: Jury selection
cases.question: Did prosecutors violate the Constitution’s promise of due process and a fair trial by striking all potential black jurors from a case involving the murder of a white woman by a black man?
cases.analysis: The Supreme Court ruled in 1986 that jurors cannot be dismissed from jury duty simply because of their race. In one of several death penalty cases before the court this term, the prosecution’s notes from jury selection appear to show its efforts to exclude black jurors.
cases.argument_for: Attorneys for Timothy Foster, who was 18 when he was charged with murder in Georgia, contend prosecutors were racially motivated and discriminated against him by getting an all-white jury to convict and sentence him to death. They say he deserves a new sentencing hearing.

cases.quote_2: “I don't see how this can be done in other than a very slap­dash fashion.”
cases.quote_1: “For all of the workers, there was certain basic equipment. There was basic sanitary gear, but there was also basic protective gear.”
cases.argument_against: The company argues that its 1,300 employees have 420 different jobs requiring different clothing and equipment, so they could not have suffered the same injury and cannot sue as a class.
cases.title: Class actions
cases.question: Can a class-action lawsuit be certified and damages awarded based on statistical techniques that assume all of the plaintiffs suffered the same basic injury?
cases.analysis: This is one of two new cases challenging the way lower courts allow lawyers to file lawsuits on behalf of thousands of people — a practice the justices have sought to restrict.
cases.argument_for: Workers at a Tyson Foods meat processing plant in Iowa claim they should have been paid overtime for putting on and taking off protective equipment.

cases.quote_2: “There is a voting interest. But there is also a representation interest.”
cases.quote_1: “It is called ‘one person, one vote.’ That seems to be designed to protect voters.”
cases.argument_against: Defenders of the “one-person, one-vote” system say all residents of a political jurisdiction deserve equal representation, whether they are allowed to vote or not.
cases.title: One person, one vote
cases.question: Should states such as Texas be required to apportion state legislative districts based on the number of voters, rather than the current method, which uses total population?
cases.analysis: States must use total population for congressional districts; all choose to do that for state legislatures. Switching to voters would pack more people into districts with large numbers of non-voters, such as illegal immigrants, likely benefiting Republicans elsewhere.
cases.argument_for: Challengers to the current system say voters, not people, should have relatively equal political clout. They say the current system gives fewer voters in some districts a greater voice than larger numbers of voters in other districts.

cases.quote_2: “People in the universities and elsewhere are worried that we will … kill affirmative action through a death by a thousand cuts.”
cases.quote_1: “If you look at an individual person, can you tell whether that person was admitted solely because of race?”
cases.argument_against: The university says about 25% of admission placements should be reserved for other non-academic factors, including race, to assure a truly heterogeneous mix of students.
cases.title: Affirmative action
cases.question: Is the student admissions system used by the University of Texas at Austin, which includes race as one factor in a “holistic” approach to filling a small part of the class, unconstitutional?
cases.case_name: Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin
cases.analysis: The challenge brought by Abigail Fisher, a white woman denied admission in 2008, is back after the court voted 7-1 in 2013 to subject the university’s policy to tougher scrutiny. Conservative justices may be ready to strike down racial preferences.
cases.argument_for: Attorneys for Fisher say the school’s primary method of achieving racial diversity – automatically admitting the top 8% of students from every high school in the state – is sufficient, and race should not be a factor in rounding out the class.

cases.quote_2: “This is a case in which there are tens of thousands of contracts with these provisions. Those contracts affect millions of employees.”
cases.quote_1: “The union basically is making these teachers ‘compelled riders’ for issues on which they strongly disagree.”
cases.argument_against: Since federal law requires that they represent all teachers, the unions say all should pay at least for collective bargaining. Those who object to the union’s lobbying and political donations already can opt out of those payments.
cases.title: Public sector unions
cases.question: Should public employee unions be precluded from charging non-members for the costs of representing them, if those workers do not want to contribute?
cases.analysis: This is the third time since 2012 that the court will examine payments made by objecting workers for unions’ mandated representation. Conservative justices appear poised to eliminate that requirement, which would be a major blow to the unions.
cases.argument_for: Non-union members forced to pay for the legal, but not political, representation of California teachers’ unions contend that all the unions’ activities involve public policy and elected officials, and are therefore political.

cases.quote_2: “You think the issue here is the protection of the judiciary rather than providing a certain element of equal treatment for the people who are litigants?”
cases.quote_1: “Their job is to pass laws. Our job is to decide a case. When there’s a dispute under one of the laws they pass, that’s our job.”
cases.argument_against: Victims and next of kin, including from the 1983 bombing of a Marine Corps barracks in Beirut, say Congress often passes laws to benefit one party.
cases.title: Terrorism compensation
cases.question: Can Congress pass laws that are intended to direct the outcome of a particular federal court case?
cases.analysis: The financial battle pits Iran’s central bank against hundreds of survivors of past terrorist attacks, but the legal issue is about the Constitution’s separation of powers.
cases.argument_for: Iran says Congress sought to make nearly $2 billion frozen in a U.S. bank account available to terrorism victims, which only a court can do.

cases.argument_against: The state says the requirements are intended to make abortion clinics and procedures safer without imposing an undue burden on women, since all the state’s major metropolitan centers still would have at least one operating clinic.
cases.title: Abortion
cases.question: Do requirements that abortion clinics hire only doctors with admitting privileges at nearby hospitals, and meet the same standards as ambulatory surgical centers, constitute an undue burden in violation of Supreme Court precedent?
cases.analysis: The court will consider a Texas law that imposes the two requirements, following an appeals court ruling for the state that conflicts with other federal courts. It will be the first major abortion case in nine years and possibly the most important in a generation.
cases.argument_for: Operators of abortion clinics in the state claim the law is intended to limit abortions rather than protect women’s health and would force all but 10 clinics to close, making some women drive more than 250 miles for services.

cases.argument_against: Bond holders say the federal law forbids states, as well as Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia, from binding creditors to debt restructuring under state or local statutes.
cases.title: Puerto Rico debt crisis
cases.question: Should Puerto Rico’s public utilities be allowed to restructure their debt under a local statute, even though the commonwealth is precluded from doing so under the federal Bankruptcy Act?
cases.case_name: Puerto Rico v. Franklin California Tax-Free Trust
cases.analysis: Puerto Rico has a crushing, $72 billion debt that threatens bankruptcy unless it can strike a deal with creditors or get relief from Congress or the Supreme Court. The court case seeks to restructure $20 billion.
cases.argument_for: The commonwealth and its government development bank say Puerto Rico should have the same power as states to restructure debts, something Detroit did successfully under the Bankruptcy Act.

cases.argument_against: The Obama administration says those employers can order their insurers to pay the benefit, thereby avoiding any direct payment for a procedure some liken to abortion.
cases.title: Contraception
cases.question: Should religious non-profits such as charities and universities with religious objections be completely exempt from the Affordable Care Act’s mandate that female employees be offered free birth control coverage, even if their insurers – not the employers themselves -- pay for the benefit?
cases.analysis: This is the latest battle over Obamacare’s “contraceptive mandate,” which includes birth control among the coverage most employers must provide free of charge. Appeals courts have split over the issue.
cases.argument_for: More than 100 lawsuits have been filed by non-profit and for-profit businesses with religious objections that claim they should be granted the same protection as religious institutions, which do not have to get involved in contraception coverage.

cases.argument_against: Federal prosecutors say McDonnell and his wife acted criminally by interceding with state health officials in exchange for free vacations and luxury items.
cases.title: Political corruption
cases.question: What type of action by a public official on behalf of a political benefactor bearing gifts constitutes corruption?
cases.analysis: The justices’ review of former Virginia governor Robert McDonnell’s conviction for accepting gifts in exchange for government favors could set a new ethics standard.
cases.argument_for: McDonnell, a Republican, says his efforts on behalf of a businessman seeking help from the state were routine actions exercised by virtually all public officials.

cases.argument_against: A coalition of 26 Republican-led states argues that both the law and the Constitution prohibit the president from acting by executive fiat.
cases.title: Immigration
cases.question: Does the president have the authority to protect millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation without going through Congress?
cases.analysis: The battle between President Obama and Republicans will test the bounds of executive power in the midst of the 2016 presidential election.
cases.argument_for: The Justice Department says the plan merely expands on the Department of Homeland Security’s discretion to set priorities for deportation.
